ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q 1: no answer because no actual text or readings besides individual group researchQ6: pace of individual projects was good; pace of some of the lectures could have been a bit faster.Overall, the individual group meetings with instructors very valuable as were group review of projects. Some of the guest speakers, such as the gentleman from the Hartford, should not be brought back as they did not provide much value.
Working with an actual client on a realistic project was the best part of this class. The practical nature of the class is a good complement to the more academic courses being taught.

The projects themselves and working with the team and professor to ensure goals of projects were satisfied. This really simulated real life and provided exposure to companies outside Yale which was great.
Practical experience managing a client-consultant relationship and helping to solve specific problems.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I thought a fair number of the lectures didn't really add anything for students from SOM who had real-world work experience. I can see how the content may have been really helpful for non-business students and/or those without much work experience. Maybe there's no way around to develop content that's useful for everyone given the range of backgrounds/experiences of the students in the course, but I'd encourage giving some additional thought to this issue. Maybe make lectures optional?
Some of the lectures from the guest speakers as noted above.

I found the classes themselves to be worthless. The few speakers who came in were not at all impressive. In fact the person who came in from The Hartford was a poor example of whatever he was supposed to be an example of. I'm not even sure why he was there. The class was not useful to completing our consulting projects, which was the purpose/only assignment of the course. Our project had a lot to do with corporate sustainability, and it would have been useful if Dan Esty had "co-taught" the class rather than Brad Gentry, because Brad does not work on projects/topics that students were dealing with in class. Why was Brad even listed on the syllabus? He never once entered the classroom or was offered as a resource.Also, our project was extremely broad, which the professor told us going into it. We figured we could deal with it because the professor had theoretically screened all the proposals. But it turned out to be WAY too much for us, or for any other 2-person pair over the course of less than four months, to do a great job on. That was disheartening. It makes me think the prof did not provide prospective clients enough guidance, or force them to be more specific in their requests. My suspicion was verified in conversations with our client, who said she didn't really know exactly what she was getting into.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: We had weekly meetings with the professor which was incredibly helpful as we progressed on our project.
Yes - feedback from instructor was very valuable and useful in completing project. No TA.

Our semi-weekly meetings with the professor were useful sometimes, and not useful at other times. Again, it would have been better to have worked with a professor who knew more about the issues we were dealing with.
Always available. We had weekly one-on-one meetings since the beginning of class.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: always good to have a chance to do a hands-on, real-world project to apply what you're learning in other courses

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain more experience working on real problems with real clients.
To gain some environmental consulting experience and because the projects were interesting.
To get practical consulting experience. I feel like I could have gotten the same experience by taking a research request during the semester, and gotten paid for it.
To see if I was cut out for business consulting and to gain some practical experience.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Yes.
no
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
see above
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: advantages: shared workload, get input/ideas from a teammate (instead of just your own)disadvantages: none, everything worked out well, though I was a little leery of the random team assignments. would prefer to have the option of choosing my own teammate
Working in two person team was great. Both of us worked well together and were able to meet client's goals.

We definitely needed a group to do our project. However, it would have been better to have had more than two. I know the class was small this semester, smaller than in the past, but two was too few for our large project. I think we didn't do as good a job for the client as we could have with an additional person in the group.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure to choose your projects wisely. Thoroughly evaluate the questions you are being asked to answer by the client.
